title: Trait with unsized fn param compiles without feature gate

labels.name: T-types
labels.description: Relevant to the types team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I created an unimplementable trait with an unsized fn param. I expected an unsized fn param in a trait function to not compile as it is impossible to implement on stable.

I tried this code:

```rust
trait Unimplementable {
    fn foo(x: str);
}

impl Unimplementable for () {
    fn foo(x: str) {}
}
```
<https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=af9c3894dfaa7e09b5fae5b3c83ebb4b>

The trait compiles successfully, but cannot be implemented without the `unsized_fn_params` feature.

Also, the compiler suggests making the param on the impl fn a reference, an invalid signature change.

I expected to see this happen: A compile error on the trait function definition, and the compiler not suggesting an invalid change.

Instead, this happened: The trait compiles, but is impossible to implement without `unsized_fn_params`

Since the trait definition contains an unsized fn param, I would expect such a definition to be feature gated. Unsized fn params in trait definitions should be under the feature gate.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.62.0-beta.2 (daf68b1f7 2022-05-19)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: daf68b1f766e67ffe040260b15c218301853386a
commit-date: 2022-05-19
host: x86_64-apple-darwin
release: 1.62.0-beta.2
LLVM version: 14.0.4
```
